[[Camille Howard]]
[[Johnny Otis]] | website = | current_members = | past_members = | notable_instruments = }} '''Roy Milton''' (July 31, 1907 – September 18, 1983) was an [[United States|American]] [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] and [[jump blues]] [[singer]], [[drummer]] and [[bandleader]]. ==Career== Milton's grandmother was a [[Chickasaw]]. He was born in [[Wynnewood, Oklahoma|Wynnewood]], [[Oklahoma]], [[United States]],[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed November 27, 2011 and grew up on an [[Indian reservation]] before moving to [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]. He joined the [[Ernie Fields]] [[musical ensemble|band]] in the late 1920s as singer and, later, drummer.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]] | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 140 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} Moving to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] in 1933, he formed his own band, the Solid Senders, with [[Camille Howard]] on [[piano]]. He performed in local [[nightclub|clubs]] and began [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] in the 1940s, his first release being "Milton's Boogie" on his own [[record label]]. His big break came in 1945, when his "R.M. Blues", on the new [[Specialty Records|Juke Box]] label, became a [[hit record|hit]], reaching number 2 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]] and No. 20 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|pop chart]]. Its success helped establish [[Art Rupe]]'s company, which he shortly afterwards renamed [[Specialty Records]].{{cite web |url=http://www.history-of-rock.com/specialty.htm |title=Art Rupe's Specialty Records |publisher= |accessdate=2006-11-26 }} Milton and his band became a major [[concert tour|touring]] attraction, and he continued to record successfully for Specialty Records through the late 1940s and early 1950s. He recorded a total of 19 [[Top 40|Top Ten]] R&B hits, the biggest being "Hop, Skip And Jump" (# 3 R&B, 1948), "Information Blues" (# 2 R&B, 1950), and "Best Wishes" (# 2 R&B, 1951). He left Specialty in 1955. However, releases on other labels were unsuccessful, and the development of [[rock and roll]] had rendered him something of an anachronism by the middle of the decade. Nevertheless he continued to perform, appearing in 1970 as a member of [[Johnny Otis]]' band at the [[Monterey Jazz Festival]], and resumed his recording career in the 1970s with albums for [[Kent Records]] (# KST-554), "Roots Of Rock, Vol. 1: Roy Milton" and the French label, Black & Blue (# 33.114), "Instant Groove". Roy Milton ("The Grandfather Of R&B") died in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], on 18 September 1983, aged 76. His song ''Reelin And Rockin'' song appears on the 1996 Rocket Sixty-Nine release ''[[Jump Shot!]].'' ==Discography== ===Original 10" shellac (78rpm) and 7" vinyl (45rpm) releases=== *"I'll Always Be In Love With You" / "To Be Alone Blues" (Hamp-Tone 101) 1945 *"Burma Road Blues" / "Burma Road Blues, Part 2" (Hamp-Tone 104) 1945 *"Milton's Boogie" [second hit] / "Groovy Blues" [vocal by Camille Howard] (Juke Box [Specialty] 503) 1945 *"R.M.
